Scheme 1 Experimental setup utilized for the evaluation of activity and self-regeneration characteristics of catalysts. Furnace (a), quartz U-tube (b), thermocouple, tip of which is placed in the catalyst bed (c), catalyst bed (d), quartz wool bed (e), 4-way switching valve (f) and 6-port gas sampling valve (g). Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Schematic illustration of the effect of temperature and reduction period on the self-regenerative function of Cu in LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite under the redox fluctuations of the reaction atmosphere. Scheme 2 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts, *: CuO (a). SEM micrographs of LaMnO3 (b) and LaMnCu0.1O3 (c). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 H2-TPR (a) and O2-TPD (b) profiles of fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic activity of fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts for CO (a) and C3H8 (b) oxidation. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (CO + C3H8)-TPR profiles of fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Deactivation test on LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts at 700 °C for 20 h. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Self-regenerative behavior of LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst in simulated redox fluctuations of exhaust gas: O2 in feed gas was replaced by N2 for 2, 4, 6 and 8 min, then O2 was injected instead of N2. CO conversion at 130 °C (a); C3H8 conversion at 200 °C (b) and 270 °C (c). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Self-regenerative behavior of LaMnO3 catalyst in the simulated redox fluctuations of exhaust gas at 200 °C (a) and 250 °C (b). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 XPS spectra of fresh LaMnCu0.1O3 (LMCO); pre-reduced LMCO at 130 °C for 4 min (reduced-LMCO-130-4); pre-reduced LMCO at 200 °C for 4 min (reduced-LMCO-200-4); pre-reduced LMCO at 270 °C for 8 min (reduced-LMCO-270-8) by 50 mL min−1 of gas mixture of CO and C3H8 in N2; re-oxidized LMCO recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of regeneration test at 130 °C and reduction time of 4 min (re-oxidized LMCO-130-4-fifth cycle); re-oxidized LMCO recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of regeneration test at 270 °C and reduction time of 8 min (re-oxidized LMCO-270-8-fifth cycle). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XRD pattern of re-oxidized LaMnCu0.1O3 recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of regeneration test at 270 °C and reduction time of 8 min (re-oxidized LMCO-270-8-fifth cycle) in comparison to the fresh LaMnCu0.1O3 (LMCO) catalyst, *: Cu° species. Graphical abstract In order to enhance the catalytic activity of LaMnO3 perovskite catalyst and induce a regenerative property under repeated reducing-oxidizing (redox) reaction conditions, a new LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite is developed for oxidation of the simulated exhaust gas. Addition of Cu to LaMnO3 significantly enhances the specific surface area, reducibility and surface oxygen mobility of LaMnCu0.1O3, which result in the high oxidation activity of this catalyst. During the redox fluctuations using LaMnCu0.1O3, the enhancements of up to 13.4 % and 10.7 % are observed in CO and C3H8 conversions, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis clarify that Cu reversibly reduces to Cu1+ and Cu° in the reducing atmosphere and re-oxidizes to Cu2+ in the oxidizing atmosphere. The activity enhancement is finally concluded to be due entirely to the formation of Cu1+ species during the reduction period. Therefore, the repeatable activity enhancement and regeneration of LaMnCu0.1O3 offer it as an “intelligent” and stable catalyst. Keywords Perovskite Catalytic converter Copper Intelligent Regenerative Exhaust gas 1 Introduction Design of a cost-effective automotive converter catalyst with a stable structure and high performance is a main demand for the treatment of exhaust gas, which could be one of the main actions to tackle the air pollution problems [1,2]. The gasoline engines have adopted a feedback control system equipped with an oxygen sensor which leads to a periodic fluctuation of the environment of automotive exhaust gas between the oxidizing and reducing atmospheres during the operation of catalytic converters [3,4]. Therefore, the ability of adapting the catalyst structure to this environment is of great importance. Among the various catalysts, perovskite-type mixed metal oxides with the general formula of ABO3 have been considered as the potential candidates for automobile pollution treatment because of their high catalytic activity, good thermal stability and low cost [5–7]. The main advantages of perovskite structures originate from the ability to accommodate a variety of ions of different valences in A- or B-sites giving tunable properties for the perovskite catalysts [8,9]. In comparison to many perovskite structures, LaMnO3 has represented relatively high catalytic activity for oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons [1,10]. However, in order to increase the durability of such catalysts through the oscillating high-temperature redox reaction conditions, Pd, Pt and Rh noble metals are doped in their structures. The noble metal in oxide form reversibly diffuses into the perovskite lattice in the oxidizing atmosphere and segregates out and disperses as metallic nanoparticles on the perovskite surface in the reducing atmosphere. Such a perovskite structure exhibiting self-regenerative characteristic is named as an “intelligent” catalyst [11,12]. Sartipi et al. [3] studied the effect of the partial reduction of Pd from the bulk of LaCo0.95Pd0.05O3 perovskite structure onto its surface for the exhaust gas treatment. According to this report, the reduction of the catalyst for a proper duration of time significantly enhances the oxidation activity of the catalyst, due to segregation of Pd from the perovskite lattice and its dispersion on the catalyst surface as metallic nanoparticles. In other studies, it has been shown that the high catalytic activities of LaFe0.95Pd0.05O3 [13], LaFe0.57Co0.38Pd0.05O3 [14], and YFe0.9Pd0.1O3 [15] can be due to the self-regenerative function of Pd in the perovskite structures. By using the techniques of X-ray absorption fine-structure measurement, resonant inelastic X-ray scattering and transmission electron microscopy, the self-regenerative properties of Rh- and Pt-doped CaTiO3 [16], CaZr0.95Pt0.05O3 [17] and LaCo1-x-yPdxZnyO3 [18] perovskites under consecutive redox treatments have been demonstrated. Despite the high catalytic activity of noble metal-doped perovskites, high prices and limited sources of them have been restricting their extensive applications as exhaust gas treatment catalysts. Therefore, it is a necessity to continue the search for alternative compounds to replace the noble metals as well as to have a self-regenerative function [19]. It has been demonstrated that the partial substitution of metals in the A or B sites with Cu can strongly influence catalyst reducibility and catalytic activity [5,20]. A series of La1-yFe1-xCuxO3 catalysts with y = 0 and 0.33, and x = 0, 0.17 and 0.2 were investigated as automotive converter catalysts, where the combination of lanthanum deficiency and iron substitution by copper in LaFeO3 contributed to the activity enhancement for CO and propene oxidation [19,20]. Tien-Thao et al. [21] suggested the application of LaCo1−xCuxO3 perovskite structures for alcohol synthesis, and Glisenti et al. [22] focused on the activity of such catalyst for steam reforming of methanol and ethanol. It has been also reported that LaMn0.8Cu0.2O3 and LaCo0.8Cu0.2O3 are more active in the NO decomposition, compared to the undoped ones [23]. In other reports, it has been shown that among various LaCo1 −x Cu x O3 (0≤x≤0.5) perovskites used for exhaust gas treatment reactions under a simulated gas including steam, NO, CO2 and hydrocarbons, LaCo0.5Cu0.5O3 exhibits an interesting characteristic of oxidation and NO reduction functionality [24]. Through catalytic removal of NO by CO using a series of LaNi0.5M0.5O3 (M = Co, Mn and Cu) perovskite catalysts, LaNi0.5Cu0.5O3showed better catalytic performance. It has been reported that the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu1+ is essential for the chemisorption of CO, and oxygen vacancies accelerate the dissociation of NO [25]. Wu et al. [26] also modified LaFeO3 perovskite structure through substitutions of La by Ca and Fe by Cu in order to promote oxygen storage capacity. The La0.6Ca0.2Fe0.8Cu0.2O3 sample showed high activity, more likely due to copper species as well as defective sites. In addition, for other Cu-based materials (e.g., Cu/CeO2 [27], Cu/SiO2 [28], Cu2O/TiO2 [29] and CuO/TiO2 [30]) applied for oxidation reactions, depending on the reaction conditions, three different states of copper have been suggested as the catalyst active sites. Therefore, it is assumed that copper metal can be a promising alternative for noble metals because of its unique physicochemical properties in reduction and oxidation reactions as well as abundance and low cost [28,31]. In the present study, the perovskite-type LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst is demonstrated as a possible automotive converter catalyst with a self-regenerative feature and high activity during the redox fluctuation of the synthesized exhaust gas. To the best of our knowledge no scientific research has been reported so far on this type of perovskite structure. To improve the redox property and catalytic activity of LaMnO3 catalyst, Cu is added in the perovskite structure. The effect of excess Cu in the perovskite structure on the catalytic activity is discussed using the various characterization techniques including scanning electron microscope (SEM), BET surface area, H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) and (CO + C3H8)-TPR. The redox environment is simulated by substitution of O2 with N2 in the exhaust gas for various times at different temperatures. The most important oxidation state of the copper, i.e., Cu2+, Cu1+ or Cu0, responsible for the high performance and intelligent characteristic of LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst in the redox reactions, is determined by an XPS technique. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalysts preparation Perovskite catalysts of nominal chemical formula LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 were synthesized via a gel combustion method [32]. Stoichiometric amounts of the metal nitrates of Mn(NO3)2.4H2O, La(NO3)3.6H2O and Cu(NO3)2.2H2O (all high purity salts from Merck), and sorbitol (C6H14O6, from Merck) were dissolved in 2 ml of deionized water in a ceramic plate. The solution was put in a microwave oven (850 W) for 30 s. As water evaporated, an increase in the temperature occurred and finally a dark brown spongy powder was resulted. The resulting powder was hand-grounded and subsequently calcined at 700 °C for 5 h. The prepared perovskite catalysts were pressed into pellets using isostatic pressure of 100 MPa and then the pellets were crushed and sieved to particle size of 0.125−0.297 mm (50–120 mesh size). 2.2 Catalysts characterization To determine the catalysts crystal structures, X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) using a Bruker AXS D8 Advanced powder X-ray diffractometer (Cu Kα, 40 kV, 40 mA) was applied. Typically, measurements were performed from 2θ = 20° to 70° at a count rate of 2° min−1 at ambient conditions. The mean crystallite sizes of the catalysts (dXRD ) were calculated from XRD line-broadening measurement using the Debye-Scherrer’s method represented in Eq. (1): (1) d X R D = 0.9 λ β c o s θ where λ is the wavelength (1.7889°A), β is the peak width at its half maximum and θ is the Bragg diffraction angle. The morphology and elemental composition of the catalysts were analysed using a Philips XL 30 conventional SEM equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). The BET, O2-TPD and H2-TPR analysis were conducted using a Quantachrome CHEMBET-3000 instrument. The detailed characterization procedures are discussed in Supplementary Material file. Using the BET specific surface area values, the mean particle sizes (dBET ) were estimated by Eq. (2): (2) d B E T = 6 B E T s u r f a c e a r e a × ρ where ρ is the skeletal density of perovskite catalysts which is about 6.55 g cm−3 [4,6]. Temperature programmed reduction experiment with a gas mixture of 6.0 mol% CO and 0.2 mol% C3H8 in N2, as reducing components of a synthetic exhaust gas used in this study, ((CO + C3H8)-TPR) was performed to investigate the redox properties of the catalysts under the synthesized exhaust gas. The detailed procedure can be found in Supplementary Material file. The XPS spectra were obtained with a Kratos XSAM800 spectrometer equipped with Al Kα radiation (12 kV ×15 mA, 1486.6 eV) under ultrahigh vacuum (10-8 torr). The binding energies were calibrated internally by carbon deposit C1s at 284.6 eV. The samples were outgassed at room temperature under pure hydrogen prior to analysis. In addition, to determine the concentrations of Mn3+ and Mn4+ ions, iodometry method (redox titration) was also carried out [6]. In this test, upon the treatment of catalysts (0.010 g) with hydrochloric acid, tri- and tetra-valent manganese species were reduced to Mn2+ and the evolved chlorine was reduced in situ with potassium iodide. The liberated iodine was subsequently titrated with sodium thiosulfate solution. This procedure can be summarized in the following reactions: 2 M n 3 + + 2 C l - → C l 2 + 2 M n 2 + M n 4 + + 2 C l - → C l 2 + M n 2 + C l 2 + 2 I - → 2 C l - + I 2 I 2 + 2 S 2 O 3 2 → S 4 O 6 2 - + 2 I - Based on the molarity and the consumed volume of sodium thiosulfate solution, the content of Mn3+ and Mn4+ in each catalyst was estimated. Amount of oxygen was calculated in a similar way reported in the literature [31]. 2.3 Catalytic activity The catalytic activities of the prepared catalysts for oxidation of the synthesized exhaust gas pollutants were evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz micro reactor (inner diameter of 0.6 cm, length of 40 cm) on 100 mg of each catalyst sample. The reactor was positioned in an electrical furnace and its temperature was programmed by a thermocouple, placed inside the catalyst bed, and a temperature controller. A gas mixture of 6.0 mol% CO and 0.2 mol% C3H8, as hydrocarbon model compound, in N2 together with proper amount of air as a synthetic exhaust gas was passed through the reactor at a flow rate of 50 ml min−1. By using mass flow controllers, the molar ratio of oxygen to the sum of the equivalents of reductants (i.e., 2[O2]/[CO]+5[C3H8]) was set on 1.1. The catalytic runs were performed at the temperatures ranging from the ambient temperature to 500 °C. After achieving the steady-state (SS) conditions at a desired temperature, effluent gases of CO, C3H8 and CO2 were detected by a gas chromatograph equipped with a methanizer and an FID detector (Shimadzu model GC-8A). To measure the CO and C3H8 concentrations in the feed gas, the reactor feed gas was directly bypassed into the gas chromatograph. The temperatures required for 50 % and 90 % conversion of CO and/or C3H8 was defined as T50 and T90, respectively. In order to investigate the thermal deactivation of the catalysts, the catalysts were heated under the feed gas mixture up to 700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. After a 2-h exposure to the gas flow at 700 °C, the reactor temperature was lowered down to 200 °C under the same flow rate of the feed gas. The C3H8 and CO conversions were measured after the SS conditions were achieved at 200 °C. The reactor temperature was again raised to 700 °C and this procedure was repeated 10 times for each catalyst. The self-regenerative behaviour of the catalysts was studied by switching off the air stream in the synthesized exhaust gas for various time intervals (i.e., 2, 4, 6 and 8 min) at specified temperatures (i.e., 130, 200 and 270 °C). A 4-way valve was used for switching between air and N2, to have the total flow rate of 50 ml min−1 during the experiments. During the switching between the reducing gas mixture of CO and C3H8, and the gas containing O2, no significant temperature changes were observed. Before each test, the catalyst was treated under the synthesized exhaust gas at 700 °C for 1 h, then was cooled down to the desired temperature (i.e., 130, 200 and 270 °C), at which the stable catalytic performance was confirmed by the 1-h operation. The reactor effluent gas was analyzed on-line by the FTIR spectrometer with the previously described characteristics. The CO and C3H8 concentrations were determined from the FTIR peak areas in the ranges of 2230−2030 cm−1 and 3040−2830 cm-1, respectively. There was also a set of valves which allowed by-passing of the reactor feed directly into the FTIR gas cell providing the direct measurement of the CO and C3H8 concentration in the feed gas. The experimental setup applied for the investigation of the activity and regeneration properties of the catalysts is illustrated in Scheme 1 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization results The XRD spectra of the fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 a. The spectra confirm the formation of perovskite structures with the orthorhombic phase (JCPDS 32-0484) for both samples. In addition, a peak at about 2θ = 38.1° is observed for LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst which corresponds to the presence of CuO phase (JCPDS 80-1268). The mean crystallite sizes (dXRD ) of the LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskites, estimated using the Eq. (1), are 21 nm and 18 nm, respectively. The LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite catalysts have BET specific surface areas of 8 m2 g−1 and 15 m2 g−1, respectively. About 88 % increase in the surface area of the perovskite catalyst is observed after addition of copper, due probably to the formation of separate CuO particles, as shown in the XRD pattern of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst. The increase in the surface area of a perovskite structure by addition of excess metal in its B-sites has been reported in the literature [6]. The average particle sizes (dBET ) of the LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskites, using Eq. (2), are estimated to be about 114 nm and 61 nm, respectively. The larger values of dBET in comparison to the dXRD values may be due to crystallites aggregation, which is quite possible for nanoparticles. The ratio of dBET to dXRD has been defined as the degree of particles aggregation [33]. The degree of aggregation is calculated to be about 5.4 and 3.4 for the LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3, respectively. The lower aggregation degree of the LaMnCu0.1O3 particles in comparison to that of the LaMnO3 particles can be due to the separate CuO phase in LaMnCu0.1O3 structure. According to the literature, the separate metal oxide phase dispersed in the perovskite structure can reduce the aggregation of particles [34]. The SEM images represent spongy morphologies for both prepared catalysts (Fig. 1b and c). According to the literature [9,31,35], the spongy-like morphology of the catalysts is due to the generation of gas in a short period of time during the combustion synthesis. The results of EDX conﬁrmed the presence of about 2.5 ± 0.1 wt.% Cu for the LaMnCu0.1O3 sample, being in a good agreement with the nominal composition of the catalyst. The results of H2-TPR analysis are illustrated in Fig. 2 a. The amount of H2 uptake was calculated after deconvolution of the H2-TPR peaks via Gaussian peak ﬁtting and reported in Table 1 . Two reduction stages are observed in the TPR proﬁle of LaMnO3 perovskite. According to the literature [35], the ﬁrst reduction stage with a peak centered at 395 °C is accounted to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ ions. This result also reveals the existence of about 31 % Mn4+ in LaMnO3 perovskite structure, which is in agreement with the results reported previously [36]. The reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ makes the peak at 900 °C [35]. From the calculated amounts of H2-uptake for the second reduction peak (Table 2 ) the whole reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ cannot occur at this temperatures because it is lower than 1 mol H2  mol−1 perovskite. In addition, due to thermodynamic limitations, the reduction of MnO to metallic Mn may be possible only at temperatures above 900 °C [37,38]. Following the addition of Cu in LaMnO3, i.e., LaMnCu0.1O3, the ﬁrst reduction peak is shifted to 257 °C which is 138 °C lower than that for LaMnO3. Also, a peak with a shoulder are distinguished at low temperatures of 167 °C and 120 °C, respectively, which can be attributed to the reduction of Cu2+ ions to Cu1+ and then reduction of Cu1+ to metallic copper [31,39]. However, the amount of H2 uptake for the ﬁrst reduction peak of LaMnCu0.1O3 (see Table 1), is much higher than that (0.1 mol mol-1 catalyst) expected for the complete reduction of Cu2+ ions to Cu°. In addition, the amount of H2 consumption measured for the second peak is much higher than that observed for reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ in LaMnO3. Therefore, it can be concluded that not only Cu facilitates the reduction of highly reducible Mn4+ ions and shifts its reduction to lower temperatures, but also it leads to the enhancement of Mn4+ in the perovskite structure (39 %). It has been recognized that hydrogen can dissociate at the surface of already reduced species, i.e., Cu1+ or Cu°, and consecutively spillover to the whole support [31,39]. This may be responsible for the lower reduction temperature of LaMnCu0.1O3 sample in comparison to that of LaMnO3 sample. It is observed that the high temperature peak (at 900 °C) remains almost intact. Using the iodometry method, it is observed that the exact structural formula of LaMnO3 is LaMnO3.16, and in which the contents of Mn4+ and Mn3+ are 0.32 and 0.68, respectively. The exact formula of LaMnCu0.1O3 is also LaMnCu0.1O3.27 with Mn4+ and Mn3+ contents of 0.37 and 0.63, respectively. These results are consistent with the results approximately calculated using the deconvolution of H2-TPR peaks. Fig. 2b exhibits the results of O2-TPD experiments and the calculated amounts of desorbed oxygen from TPD peaks are summarized in Table 1. Desorbed oxygen can be categorized as α- and β-oxygen, using the temperature of 500 °C as the separation point. The α-oxygen and β-oxygen are ascribed to the adsorbed oxygen to the surface anion vacancies and the lattice oxygen in the perovskite framework, respectively [9,40]. For both catalysts, the α-oxygen peaks are relatively small, while the β-oxygen peaks are more intense. According to Fig. 2b and Table 1, the amount of α-oxygen desorption for LaMnCu0.1O3 is higher than that for LaMnO3, suggesting that the existence of Cu can generate more oxygen vacancies over the perovskite. A slight decrease in the amount of β-oxygen desorption is realized for the LaMnCu0.1O3 sample, however it takes place at relatively lower temperatures compared to that of the LaMnO3 sample. This may suggest that the lattice oxygen mobility in the perovskite is improved via addition of Cu. These results are in good agreement with the results reported for the ABO3 perovskite structures with excess metal in the B-site [34]. 3.2 Catalytic activity and thermal stability of catalysts Fig. 3 presents the activity results of the fresh LaMnO3 and LaMnCu0.1O3 catalysts for oxidation of CO and C3H8. The catalysts show the sharp S-shape proﬁles for CO oxidation and the sluggish ones for C3H8 conversion. The results indicate that the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst is more active than the LaMnO3 catalyst as T50 values of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst for CO and C3H8 oxidation are about 72 °C and 20 °C lower than those of the LaMnO3 catalyst, respectively. The activity enhancement by nearly 90 °C and 23 °C decreases in T90 values for CO and C3H8 oxidation, respectively, is also observed by addition of excess Cu to LaMnO3 catalyst, i.e., LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst. It is worth to mention that among various LaMnCuxO3 (x = 0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4) perovskite-type catalysts prepared by the present authors, LaMnCu0.1O3, the one investigated in this study, showed the highest activity (characterization and catalytic activity results presented in Supplementary Material file, Fig. S1-4). The CO and C3H8 oxidation at low temperatures (i.e., below 500 °C) is proposed to be a so-called suprafacial reaction where the adsorbed oxygen (α-oxygen) reacts with CO and C3H8 in the gas phase and then the reduced surface site is re-oxidized by oxygen from the gas phase [41,42]. According to the literature [9], the easier the redox properties, the faster the oxidation reactions. In other words, the higher catalytic activity of LaMnCu0.1O3 compared to LaMnO3 can be described by the higher reducibility and the more α-oxygen content of this catalyst (Fig. 2 and Table 1). This hypothesis can be further confirmed by the results of the (CO + C3H8)-TPR experiment (Fig. 4 ). The (CO + C3H8)-TPR spectrum of LaMnO3 exhibits two broad and continuous peaks centered at 440 °C and 570 °C and a peak at higher temperature (900 °C). According to the literature, the reduction of metal oxides occurs at two stages of surface reduction, in which the outer layers are firstly reduced, and bulk reduction related to the deeply reduction of inner layers of crystallites [6]. Therefore, the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ is seen in two continuous peaks at 440 °C and 570 °C. The peak at the high temperature (900 °C) is related to the reduction of the Mn3+ species to Mn2+, where the reduction of the whole Mn2+ to metallic Mn is impossible at this temperature [37,38]. For the LaMnCu0.1O3 sample, an extra peak with a shoulder are distinguished at 210 °C and 145 °C, respectively, most likely being related to the reduction of Cu2+ to metallic copper. The main peak ascribing to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ is occurred at lower temperature (the peak centered at 300 °C) compared to that of the LaMnO3 sample. The high temperature peak (centered at 900 °C) is remains almost unchanged. Considering the degree of reducibility and reduction peak temperatures, it is indicated that the reducibility characteristics of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst under CO and C3H8 atmosphere is better than that of the LaMnO3 sample. Therefore, the easy changes of cations oxidation states for the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst beneﬁt its higher catalytic activity in comparison to the LaMnO3 catalyst. It is also observed that the enhancement in the activity of LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst (i.e., the decreases in T50 and T90 values) is lower for C3H8 oxidation compared to CO oxidation. This result can be related to the oxidation state of copper at various temperatures. According to the H2- and (CO + C3H8)-TPR results (Figs. 2a and 4, respectively), CuO reduces to Cu° at temperatures above 200 °C. It is believed that the metallic Cu has poor activity for hydrocarbon oxidation [28,43], thus the possible reduction of CuO to Cu° at high temperatures may account for the lower activity enhancement for oxidation of C3H8 compared CO oxidation. A brief description of oxidation reaction mechanism of catalysts may be useful to explain the higher catalytic activity of LaMnCu0.1O3. Oxidation reaction of CO and hydrocarbons on metal oxides are often described by means of the Mars and van Krevelen model [6]. This mechanism involves a two-step redox reaction: (I) reaction of reducing reactants (CO and hydrocarbon) and the active oxygen of catalyst and (II) reoxidation of reduced surface site by oxygen in the gas phase. The reaction sites for LaMnO3 catalysts are manganese ions (Mn3+ and Mn4+), and for LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst, they are Mn3+, Mn4+, Cu2+ and Cu1+. Therefore, the redox reaction takes place at these sites by consuming and regenerating weakly adsorbed oxygen. According to this mechanism, two independent steps are distinguished for CO and propane oxidation: R + O–Mn4+ → P + –Mn3+ and/or R + O–Cu2+ → P + –Cu1+ O2 + –Mn3+ → O–Mn4+ and /or O2 + –Cu1+ → O–Cu2+ where, R and P are the reactants and products, respectively. This model assumes that the gaseous oxygen reaction with the surface occurs when a reduced site is available (Mn3+ and/or Cu1+). In other words, the formation of B-site metal at high oxidation state, i.e., Mn4+ for LaMnO3, and Mn4+ and Cu2+ for LaMnCu0.1O3, and easy reoxidation of reduced site (Mn3+ and/or Cu1+) are the limiting factor in the kinetics. It is worth to mention that the increasing of vacancies in B site, i.e., addition of Cu in LaMnO3 perovskite leads to the enhancement of Mn4+ and obviously creation of Cu2+ as well as enhancement of oxygen vacancy (see perovskite formula of LaMnO3.16 and LaMnCu0.1O3.27). The higher activity of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst, therefore, is due entirely to the high contents of Mn4+, Cu2+ and oxygen vacancy as well as easy reoxidation of Cu1+. According to the literature, addition of optimum amount of Cu to the perovskite catalysts remarkably improve their oxidation activity. For example, LaFe0.8Cu0.2O3 showed T50 value of 220 °C for CO oxidation under GHSV of 60000 mL g−1 h−1 [20], LaMn0.8Cu0.2O3 and LaCo0.8Cu0.2O3 suggested for CO oxidation, which resulted in T50 value of 200 °C at GHSV of 15000 mL g−1 h−1 [23], and LaCo0.5Cu0.5O3 applied for CO oxidation under GHSV of 90000 mL g−1 h−1 also led to T50 value of 280 °C [24]. LaNi0.5Cu0.5O3 under GHSV of 36000 mL g−1 h−1 and La0.6Ca0.2Fe0.8Cu0.2O3 under GHSV of 60000 mL g−1 h−1 have been recommended for CO oxidation representing T50 values of 275 and 300 °C, respectively [25,26]. Therefore, in comparison to these reports, the presented LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite catalyst showed very high activity (T50 value of 115 °C for CO oxidation at GHSV of 30000 mL g−1 h−1). Thermal stability of catalysts operated at the elevated temperatures is important issue to extend their practical applications. Fig. 5 presents the thermal stability of LaMnCu0.1O3 and LaMnO3 catalysts under the reaction gas stream at 700 °C for 20-h run time. The CO and C3H8 conversion were measured after cooling down the reactor temperature from 700 °C to 200 °C. Results reveals that the activities of both catalysts reduce by no more than 2.1 % for both CO and C3H8 oxidation suggesting that the prepared catalysts maintain their activities in the run period. 3.3 Intelligent regeneration of LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst The self-regenerative behaviour of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst, when air in the feed gas is replaced by N2 (i.e., reducing atmosphere) for various periods of time and then N2 is replaced by air (i.e., oxidizing atmosphere) again, was studied at different temperatures (Fig. 6 ). The temperatures of 130, 200 and 275 °C are chosen for the regenerative tests, at which the conversions of CO are about 80, 100 and 100 %, and those of C3H8 are near 0, 45 and 80 %, respectively (from Section 3.2, Fig. 3). Fig. 6a shows the alterations of CO conversion at 130 °C and Fig. 6b and c presents the changes of C3H8 conversion at 200 and 275 °C, during the regenerative redox reactions. Fig. 6 shows that the CO and C3H8 conversions gradually decrease with time on stream under reducing atmosphere. After the reduction period, by introducing of air into the feed gas, CO and C3H8 conversion values sharply increase to the values higher than those of the SS operation and then gradually level off to the SS ones. The enhancements in CO and C3H8 conversions after exposing of the catalyst to the reducing atmosphere for various time intervals compared to those of the SS operation are summarized in Table 2. It is indicated that the maximum enhancement in CO oxidation is achieved at 130 °C and a reduction period of 4 min. The optimum values of reduction temperature and period for the maximum enhancement of C3H8 conversion are 200 °C and 4 min, respectively. Furthermore, Fig. 6a and b shows that the significant enhancements in CO and C3H8 conversions level off to their SS values in 15 min, under the optimum reduction conditions, i.e., the temperatures of 130 °C and 200 °C and a reduction period of 4 min. In contrast, for the 2, 6 and 8 min reduction times at both aforementioned temperatures, the CO and C3H8 conversions rapidly reach to their SS values, i.e., in 4, 9 and 5 min in O2-containing atmosphere, respectively. It is worth mentioning that the conversions were remained stable at the SS values, as the time on stream is increased beyond 20 min (data not shown). In addition, over repeating of the self-regeneration assay for 5 cycles at 130 °C and 200 °C, a stable performance of the catalyst for the CO and C3H8 oxidation is observed (Fig. 6a and b insets). These overshoots of CO and C3H8 conversions after a period of reduction and the repeatable behaviour of catalyst in the fluctuating redox reaction conditions are called the intelligent regeneration of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst. At the reduction temperature of 270 °C (Fig. 6c), the enhancements in C3H8 conversion are lower than those obtained at the reduction temperature of 200 °C for all the reduction durations. Moreover, the conversions more rapidly decrease to the SS values and even the values lower than the initial ones for the reduction times of 6 and 8 min. By repeating this experiment at 270 °C for 5 times (Fig. 6c inset), the changes in C3H8 conversion over the 5 cycles at the reduction durations of 2 and 4 min are almost similar to those of the first cycles, while for 6 and 8 min reduction durations, the C3H8 conversion starts to decrease after the second cycle. For the sake of comparison, the self-regeneration tests were also carried out for the LaMnO3 catalyst at 200 °C and 250 °C (Fig. 7 ). The CO and C3H8 conversions rapidly decrease to low levels in reducing conditions, after which the conversions slowly i.e., in 5−8 min) increase to the SS values in the oxidizing conditions. In other words, the LaMnO3 catalyst did not show any intelligent behaviour during the redox reactions. The presence of Cu and most importantly its different oxidation states on the catalyst surface, i.e., Cu2+, Cu1+ or Cu°, are believed to be essential for the regenerative behaviour of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst. Hence, to study the changes in copper oxidation states, the XPS analyses were performed on six samples; the fresh LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst, the ones reduced at 130 °C and 200 °C for 4 min, the one reduced at 270 °C for 8 min, and the catalysts recovered after the fifth cycle of the experiments performed at 130 °C for a reduction period of 4 min and at 270 °C for a reduction period of 8 min. The results of the XPS analyses are shown in Fig. 8 . The characteristic peaks at the binding energies of 933.76, 932.18 and 932.63 eV are related to Cu2+, Cu1+ and Cu° species, respectively [44]. According to a method reported in the literature [45], the proportional contents of Cu2+, Cu1+ and Cu° species on the catalyst surface are quantified by the determination of corresponding peaks areas using Gaussian peak ﬁttings (Table 3 ). The total peak area of Cu2+ species includes the area of peak centered at 933.76 eV and the area of shake-up peak presented in a wide binding energy from 940 eV to 946 eV, which is reported to be due to the d9 Cu2+ species [44]. The results indicate that Cu2+ is the main species on the surface of the fresh catalyst. However, according to the literature [19,31], Cu1+ species may exist in the perovskite structure, which is not detected by XPS technique. By exposing the catalyst to the reducing atmosphere at 130 °C, some Cu2+ species (21 %) are reduced to the Cu1+ ones. The proportional content of Cu1+ increases to its highest value as the reduction temperature is increased to 200 °C, at which about 50 % of Cu2+ is reduced to Cu1+ species. At the reduction temperature of 270 °C, the Cu° species (by 70 %) are dominated on the catalyst surface (Table 3). According to the literature [25,46,47], the step-wise reduction of Cu2+ to Cu1+ and then to Cu° can be due to the fact that reduction activation energy of CuO is much lower than that of Cu2O. The XPS spectrum of the catalyst recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of the regeneration experiments performed at 130 °C for 4 min reduction period shows that the catalyst recovers its structure as all the Cu1+ species re-oxidize to Cu2+. In other words, Cu shows self-regenerative function at the aforementioned redox reaction conditions. The XPS spectrum of the catalyst recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of the regeneration experiment carried out at 270 °C for 8 min reduction period shows that some Cu° species (17 %) are not re-oxidized to the Cu2+ and remain on the catalyst surface. This result may suggest that some of the metallic copper species are sintered on the surface of this catalyst after treatment under the redox conditions at the high temperature of 270 °C. Moreover, the BET surface area of re-oxidized LaMnCu0.1O3 recovered at the end of the fifth cycle of regeneration test at 200 and 270 °C and reduction time of 8 min were analyzed. It was observed that BET surface area of the sample tested under 200 °C were almost similar to that of the fresh catalyst. i.e., 8 m2 g−1. However, for the LaMnCu0.1O3 sample tested under 270 °C and reduction time of 8 min, the reduction of BET surface area from 15 m2 g−1 to 11 m2 g−1, and the observation of two peaks at about 2θ = 43 and 50° in XRD pattern (Fig. 9 ), which correspond to the presence of Cu°, indicate the structural changes of this sample. Therefore, it may be suggested that the reduction of Cu2+ to other species in the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst is the main reason of the significant enhancement in the activity of LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst for CO and C3H8 oxidation. From the XPS and the regeneration experiment results, it is indicated that the catalytic activity enhancements at temperatures lower than 200 °C and reduction time of 4 min is due to the most reactive Cu1+ species, which reversibly re-oxidize to the less reactive Cu2+ in the presence of O2 leading to the decrease of the conversions to the initial SS values. The high activity of Cu1+ species for oxidation of CO and hydrocarbon has also been reported in the literature [27,29]. The intelligent performance of LaMnCu0.1O3 is similar to the well-known intelligent catalysts of LaFe0.57Co0.38Pd0.05O3 and LaFe0.95Pd0.05O3 in which Pd reversibly reduce to metallic particles in reducing atmosphere and re-oxides in oxidizing atmosphere, where the high catalytic activity is related to the reduction of PdO to the lower oxidation state [13,14]. It is also determined that under reducing atmosphere with higher temperature (i.e., 270 °C) and longer periods of reduction time (i.e., 8 min), Cu2+ species more deeply reduce to Cu° and some of Cu° species sinter on the catalyst surface, leading to the small conversion enhancements during the regeneration time and declining of the activity after the second cycle of the regeneration tests. According to the literature [28,43], the metallic Cu has poor activity for hydrocarbon oxidation. The effects of temperature and time period of reduction stage on the self-regenerative function of Cu in LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite through the redox reactions are schematically illustrated in Scheme 2 . Overall, at the optimum reduction conditions, LaMnCu0.1O3 is a self-regenerative catalyst with high activity for oxidation of the synthesized exhaust gas pollutants including CO and C3H8. 4 Conclusions In summary, the effects of excess Cu in LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite catalyst on oxidation of CO and C3H8 as exhaust gas pollutants and the catalyst self-regenerative property under redox reaction conditions are investigated and compared with those of LaMnO3. Resulting from the presence of Cu in LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst, the reducibility of Mn and the mobility of surface oxygen in the perovskite structure are significantly promoted, which lead to the reduction of T50 and T90 for oxidation of both CO and C3H8. Performing XPS analyses along with the redox experiments for the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst reveal that, under optimum reduction conditions, Cu reversibly reduces to Cu1+ and Cu° in the reducing atmosphere and re-oxidizes to Cu2+ in the oxidizing atmosphere. The formation of Cu1+ species during the reduction period is the reason of the catalytic activity enhancements in oxidizing atmosphere. In the reducing atmosphere, at the elevated temperature and for long periods of times, low activity enhancements of the catalyst are observed, due to the more deeply reduction of Cu2+ to the less reactive Cu° and partially sintering of them on the catalyst surface. Finally, the repeatable activity enhancement and structural regeneration of the LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst over five consecutive reuses at the optimum redox conditions, provide evidence that the presented perovskite catalyst is an “intelligent” catalyst. This study opens up new perspectives for the design of “low-cost” perovskite structures with high catalytic activities and “self-regenerative” properties for automotive exhaust gas pollutants treatment. coredata.dc:description: In order to enhance the catalytic activity of LaMnO3 perovskite catalyst and induce a regenerative property under repeated reducing-oxidizing (redox) reaction conditions, a new LaMnCu0.1O3 perovskite is developed for oxidation of the simulated exhaust gas. Addition of Cu to LaMnO3 significantly enhances the specific surface area, reducibility and surface oxygen mobility of LaMnCu0.1O3, which result in the high oxidation activity of this catalyst. During the redox fluctuations using LaMnCu0.1O3, the enhancements of up to 13.4 % and 10.7 % are observed in CO and C3H8 conversions, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis clarify that Cu reversibly reduces to Cu1+ and Cu° in the reducing atmosphere and re-oxidizes to Cu2+ in the oxidizing atmosphere. The activity enhancement is finally concluded to be due entirely to the formation of Cu1+ species during the reduction period. Therefore, the repeatable activity enhancement and regeneration of LaMnCu0.1O3 offer it as an “intelligent” and stable catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Self-regenerative function of Cu in LaMnCu0.1O3 catalyst: Towards noble metal-free intelligent perovskites for automotive exhaust gas treatment
